4.1.12. Carbonate breccia – Cb 455
Description. Dolomitic rudstone to floatstone with pebble-sized clasts of light to 456
dark beige color (Figure 10C). Commonly intercalates with centimeter-thick levels of 457
dark grey siliciclastic mudstone. Clasts are up to 3 cm in size, composed of dolomitic 458
mudstone, and can range from elongated and very angular (“pointed”), to more 459
equant and sub-rounded, with no orientation. Matrix in floatstone portions is 460
composed of fine wackestone to mudstone, presenting distorted, seemingly crinkled 461
lamination. Tiny “bladed” or “discoidal” (up to 5 mm in length) structures, filled by 462
calcite and silica cements, occur in chaotic orientation (Figure 11A). These are 463
sometimes associated to curved-up, ruptured layers (Figure 11C). Nodular structures 464
occur in clutches up to 3 cm, sometimes elongated along the lamination, resembling 465
“clouds” (Figure 11D-F). Rhomb-shaped structures up to 2 mm, are also present 466
(Figure 11B). 467
Interpretation. Brecciation in carbonate rocks can have a variety of originating 468
processes, which can work in conjunction. The tiny “bladed” and rhomb-shaped 469
structures are here interpreted as pseudomorphs of intrasediment-grown gypsum 470
crystals. The “cloud-shaped” nodules are interpreted as pseudomorphs of gypsum 471
clusters, or chicken-wire anhydrite. Curved-up and ruptured carbonate layers with 472
underlying breccia and gypsum pseudomorphs are interpreted as tepee structures. 473
Evaporite intrasediment growth indicates precipitation due to supersaturated waters, 474
although these can be sinsedimentary or early post-burial events. Tepee structures 475
are result of expansive growth of early cements within a host sediment, and are 476
indicative of shallow-water setting, either subtidal, itertidal, or supratidal. Micro-477
crenulated lamination and other criptomicrobial structures, as well as pseudomorphs 478
of anhydrite and gypsum have been observed by Araújo (2001) in the same horizon 479
of the Irati Formation, including in borehole HV-44-RS. Dolomitization is also 480
indicative of evaporitic shallow-water conditions. These characteristics combined, it is 481
here interpreted that these rocks formed under a shallow-water, hypersaline 482
environment with periodic subaerial exposure. Thus, most likely brecciation process 483
25
is considered to be mainly subaerial exposure, and also subordinately displacive 484
evaporite intra-sediment growth (Demicco and Hardie, 1994; Scholle et al., 1983). 485
4.1.13. Carbonate intraclastic conglomerate – Cr 486
Description. Dolomitic rudstone to floatstone with elongated, light beige pebble-487
sized (up to 5 cm) mudstone clasts, in a dark-beige to brownish wackestone to 488
mudstone matrix. Most clasts present a sub-horizontal to bimodal oblique orientation 489
(Figure 10E), but also occur in cross-stratification (Figure 10B). Bimodal oblique-490
oriented clasts are mostly elongated and angular, sometimes with irregular limits 491
(Figure 10E), and are commonly deformed, especially when less than 1 cm in 492
thickness (Figure 10B, E). Thicker (> 1 cm) angular clasts also commonly present 493
internal lamination, and give the impression of being “ripped up” from carbonate-rich 494
Mg facies, with upward increase in fragmentation (Figure 10E). More well-rounded 495
clasts occur usually in cross-stratification. Nodular and tiny elongated (<2 mm) 496
structures, and crinkled laminae are present, substituted by silica (Figure 11E). 497
Interpretation. Borehole HV-32-RS shows what is here interpreted as the 498
formation of intraclasts by erosion and rip-up of the semi-consolidated Mg 499
(carbonate-dominant) facies into tabular, centimeter-thick angular pebbles with 500
irregular edges (Demicco and Hardie, 1994; Scholle et al., 1983). The bimodal 501
oblique orientation of the flat-pebbles is here interpreted as a result of heterogeneous 502
liquefaction, due to upward release of pore-pressure, caused by rapid storm flow 503
(Bouchette et al., 2001). The thinner pebbles are often deformed, attesting the semi-504
consolidated state of the eroded sediment (Demicco and Hardie, 1994; Scholle et al., 505
1983). The association of angular and well-rounded clasts with cross-stratification 506
indicates relatively short transport by lower flow regime unidirectional current (Boggs, 507
2006; Demicco and Hardie, 1994). Nodular and tiny elongated structures, and 508
crinkled laminae are here interpreted to be substituted by silica, and together with 509
dolomitization indicate hypersaline shallow-water conditions (Demicco and Hardie, 510
1994; Pratt, 2010). The intraclastic flat-pebble conglomerate is thus interpreted as 511
the erosion and redeposition of semi-consolidated carbonate sediment in a shallow-512
water, evaporitic setting, caused by storm action (Bouchette et al., 2001). Variation 513
from grain-supported to matrix-supported is also a common feature for these 514
deposits (Demicco and Hardie, 1994). 515

The lower shoreface facies association is composed by the Fw and Fl facies. 544
Heterolithic bedding associated with small-sized structures (ripples) generated by 545
combined-flow are indicative of episodic storm action, near the lower limit of storm 546
wave base (Plint, 2010), and so can be considered as the distal manifestation of 547
storm action, i.e., distal tempestites (Dott and Bourgeois, 1982). Described logs show 548
a retrogradational pattern, so that mudstone dominates upwards over siltstone 549
(Figure 13). Light grey colors, together with ubiquitous bioturbation are indicative of 550
oxygenated bottom sediments (Araújo, 2001; Boggs, 2006), which in turn imply good 551
water circulation, and thus, an open communication with the outer ocean (Araújo, 552
2001). 553
The outer, mid-, and inner ramp depositional environment division is based on 554
the classification of Burchette and Wright (1992). These environments are 555
considered to integrate a carbonate ramp system in a restricted epeiric sea (Araújo, 556
2001). The restricted conditions are inferred by the excellent preservation of organic 557
matter and original depositional structures (Araújo, 2001; Goldberg, 2001). 558
The outer ramp facies association is characterized by the Ff, Fn, Hw, and Hn 559
facies. Deposition of these facies took place below or near storm wave base, so that 560
wave action could only form small-scale bedforms (ripples and lenses) and 561
microexcavations (Araújo, 2001; Plint, 2010). As in the lower shoreface environment, 562
these features are considered the distal manifestations of intermittent storm action, 563
and are regarded as distal tempestites (Dott and Bourgeois, 1982). Mesosaurid 564
bones are most common in the upper part of the studied interval, amidst these distal 565
tempestites, mainly of the Hw facies. The dysoxic to anoxic conditions, which attest 566
the onset of a restricted communication with the outer ocean, are indicated by dark 567
grey and intense black colors of mudstones and shales, presence of sulphides, and 568
preserved ichnofossils (Araújo, 2001; Boggs, 2006). The occasional levels of 569
intraclastic sandstones are considered to be generated by storm wave ravinement, 570
transgressive or regressive. Its association to mid- and outer ramp facies, but not 571
with inner ramp facies is also indicative of its origin (Catuneanu, 2006). It was not 572
31
observed in every core, so a surface could not be traced. Some rare isolated 573
grainstone layers occasionally occur, probably transported to greater depths by major 574
storms, but are still considered to be in outer ramp environment. 575
Typical mid-ramp facies are Chw, Cgl, and Cgp. These represent reworking and 576
transport of previously consolidated (or semi-consolidated) sand-sized material by 577
storm action. Reworking is attested especially by the intraclasts composed of 578
pygocephalomorph carapaces and peloids (Figure 9; Araújo, 2001; Demicco and 579
Hardie, 1994; Scholle and Ulmer-Scholle, 2003; Van Steenwinkel, 1990). High 580
energy storm events are attested by the predominance of transition to upper-flow 581
regime structures (low-angle and hummocky cross-stratification, upper-flow parallel 582
stratification; Dott and Bourgeois, 1982; Harms et al., 1975; Plint, 2010). 583
Transportation is further corroborated by the lack of in situ sediments, such as 584
carbonate mudstone matrix or articulated fossils (Demicco and Hardie, 1994; 585
Voorhies, 1969). The Chw facies is here interpreted as a transition between the Hw 586
and Cgl facies, and thus between outer and mid-ramp environments. The transition is 587
embodied by appearance or disappearance of carbonate compositions and high-588
energy structures. Occasionally siliciclastic intervals are continuous enough to be 589
considered Hw facies, but are still considered in mid-ramp while carbonate 590
grainstones are common. This succession presents typically a retrogradational stack 591
pattern. 592
Inner ramp facies are Mg, Cm, Cb, and Cr. These are characterized by in situ 593
deposited or precipitated sediments disturbed by shallow water processes, such as 594
subaerial exposure, intrasediment evaporite growth, and storm erosion. 595
The features displayed by the intraclastic conglomerate (Cr) facies are 596
characteristic of shallow-water settings (Aigner, 1985; Demicco and Hardie, 1994; 597
Pratt, 2010; Scholle et al., 1983). Additionally, lamination can be seen within the 598
clasts (which is difficult to observe in facies Mg), serving as weakness surfaces for 599
further breakage into millimeter-thick elongated angular pebbles. This internal 600
lamination corroborates an initial microbial-influenced deposition for the Mg facies. 601
Due to shallow-water context, the Mg facies is interpreted as being formed by very 602
high-frequency, shallowing-upward sequences. The deficiency of coarse- and 603
medium-sized siliciclastic sediments and shallow water wave energy in the Irati 604
32
Formation would cause the progradation of the system to be marked not by increase 605
in grain size, but by increase in production of the microbial carbonate factory, thus 606
generating the “carbonating-up” gradation. Subaerial exposure, evaporitic conditions, 607
and microbial influence on sedimentation are further corroborated by observations of 608
criptomicrobial lamination, evaporite molds, and mudcracks by Araújo (2001) in thin 609
sections of the HV-44-RS borehole. Absence of benthic fauna and bioturbation are 610
indicative of a stressed environment, probably due to high salinity (Araújo, 2001). 611
Dark grey siliciclastic mudstones (Ff and Fn facies) occur, but this intercalation is 612
common in shallow carbonate settings (Bathurst, 1987; Demicco and Hardie, 1994; 613
Pratt, 2010). Intercalated grainstones (Cgl facies) are also present, as not all grain-614
sized particles are transported to the mid-ramp. 615
4.3. Sequence Stratigraphy 616
From the facies associations displayed on the stratigraphic framework and the 617
gamma-ray profiles, significant stratigraphic surfaces could be traced, named 618
sequence boundaries (SB), maximum regressive surfaces (MRS), and maximum 619
transgressive surfaces (MTS). This led to the recognition of 3 sequences within the 620
Irati Formation: Irati Sequences 1, 2, and 3. This sequence stratigraphy framework is 621
displayed in Figure 12 and Figure 13. 622
Progradational-retrogradational patterns on the gamma-ray profiles were used as 623
guideline for correlation between core sections. However, especially for finely 624
intercalated facies the gamma-ray reading might be affected by neighboring layers 625
(Serra, 1984). Additional sedimentary features, such as presence of sulfide nodules 626
or fossil occurrence were also considered. Nevertheless, when conflicting, 627
demarcation of significant surfaces was traced considering facies change. 628
4.3.1. Irati Sequence 1 – IS1 629
The Irati Sequence 1 (IS1) starts in most boreholes at the limit between the 630
Palermo and Irati Formations, marked by a negative shift in the gamma-ray profile 631
and by the change from light grey to dark grey mudstone. The color change is usually 632
gradational and not always readily identifiable. It represents the onset of restricted 633
water circulation conditions, interpreted to be due to a base-level fall, resulting in a 634
dysoxic environment at the sediment-water interface, and probably the establishment 635
of a thermo-oxicline (Lavina, 1991). The transition is not always readily identifiable, 636
33
especially in cores in poorer conditions, so demarcation was aided by gamma-ray 637
profile. There is a subtle shift from a progradational to a retrogradational pattern and, 638
since there is no palpable facies change underlying this horizon, a lowstand systems 639
tract (LST) cannot be recognized. Therefore, the sequence boundary termed SB1 is 640
coincident with the maximum regressive surface (MRS), and marks the base of the 641
first transgressive systems tract (TST). 642
The shift from retrogradational to progradational pattern in the gamma-ray profile, 643
which marks the MTS, is also subtle in this sequence. In boreholes HV-32-RS and 644
SC-64-RS the MTS was marked on occurrence of the Hw facies. Borehole HV-22-RS 645
presents a 30 cm thick erosive, intraclastic sandstone interval, interpreted as a 646
transgressive ravinement surface. Boreholes HV-22-RS, HV-44-RS and SC-88-RS 647
show an interval with concentration of sulphide nodules. The structure preservation 648
of the Hw facies and sulphide nodule formation are considered to represent greater 649
reducing conditions, probably due to a more stratified water body, which are 650
characteristics of the MTS (Araújo, 2001; Catuneanu, 2006; Lavina, 1991). This 651
surface marks the base of the highstand systems tract (HST). 652
By these demarcations the Irati Sequence 1 is coincident with the Taquaral 653
Member lithostratigraphic unit. Deposition took place solely on outer ramp 654
environment, causing the systems tracts to have little facies differentiation in the 655
study area. Sediments are characterized by dark grey mudstones (Ff), with little 656
disturbance to the mudstone continuity except for the erosive sandstone and 657
heterolithic siltstone (Hw) horizons. Recognition of the continuity of these horizons 658
might have been prevented by poor core conditions. 659
4.3.2. Irati Sequence 2 – IS2 660
The base of this sequence (SB2) is marked by abrupt facies change from outer 661
ramp siliciclastic mudstones (Ff) to inner ramp carbonate breccia (Cb). This 662
represents a large relative sea-level fall, such that a transition through mid-ramp 663
facies is not observed. 664
Deposition continues after the base-level fall in shallow water, inner ramp 665
environment, and progressive negative response of the gamma-ray profile indicates 666
progradation. The carbonate breccias with subaerial features (Cb) are more common 667
at the base of the succession, and as observed in thin section by Araújo (2001), 668
34
criptomicrobial structures are also present, which suggest periodic subaerial 669
exposure. Predominance of these structures can be caused by limited 670
accommodation space (Pratt, 2010). However, they become less common upwards, 671
and the intraclastic conglomerates (Cr) become more common. Some studies 672
suggest carbonate mudstone without lamination might be indicative of more 673
subaqueous conditions than microbial laminites (Glumac and Walker, 1997), as is the 674
case of the mudstone clasts. Therefore, this facies succession is interpreted as 675
response to a slowly increasing rate in creation of accommodation space, allowing 676
progradation and aggradation, and thus it is interpreted as a lowstand systems tract 677
(LST). The presence of dark grey mudstones intercalated with the shallow water 678
carbonates is considered to be due to a higher frequency cycle. In addition, 679
mudstones and shales interbedded with carbonates are common features in shallow 680
water settings (Bathurst, 1987; Demicco and Hardie, 1994; Pratt, 2010). 681
Usually marked by a sharp positive break in the gamma-ray profile in the studied 682
section, the transition from the inner ramp to the mid-ramp also marks the transition 683
from a progradational to a retrogradational stacking pattern, here interpreted as a 684
MRS, and the beginning of the TST. Early TST is characterized by Mid-Ramp 685
grainstone units in isolated storm beds that have an upward tendency to be 686
progressively thinner (i.e., they are retrogradational). Carbonate sediments 687
eventually cease, and Outer Ramp bituminous shales occur together with the peak of 688
gamma-ray reading profiles, marking the MTS. 689
The overlying HST is the thickest accumulation of the 3 sequences. Oxygenation 690
levels are relatively higher, inferred by the predominance of non-bituminous facies. 691
Fish remains are more common on this tract, especially near the base. Presumably, 692
it is due the lower sedimentation rate of the early HST near the MTS, where the 693
siliciclastic outer ramp still suffers from “starvation” (Brett, 1995). 694
The Irati 2 Sequence (IS2) registers a vigorous progradation of the shoreline, so 695
that the carbonate factory moved all through the mid-ramp to overlie outer ramp 696
deposits. As base level started to rise again, water column stratification allied to high 697
organic production (Lavina, 1991; Araújo, 2001) resulted in strongly anoxic bottom 698
sediments and exceptional organic matter preservation. Progradation is then 699
resumed, with high accommodation space. 700
35
4.3.3. Irati Sequence 3 – IS3 701
Overlying the outer ramp dark grey mudstones of the HST of IS2, are sharp- and 702
erosive-based mid-ramp grainstones. The gamma-ray profile also shows a shift to a 703
progradational pattern, considered here to represent a base-level fall designated as 704
SB3. 705
Although the progradational shift of the gamma-ray profiles is usually not as 706
sharp, the lower portion of the grainstone beds is commonly formed by amalgamated 707
grainstone storm deposits (Cgl facies), which start to intercalate upward with 708
siltstones and shales (Chw facies), showing an asymmetrical progradational-709
retrogradational pattern. These mid-ramp deposits are, therefore, considered the 710
LST. In addition, 3 of the described cores showed this interval to be composed of the 711
Cp facies. 712
The formation of the intraclasts of the Cp facies required prior deposition of 713
individual elements (bioclasts, peloids, etc.), partial lithification, and subsequent 714
erosion (Morad, 1998; Scholle and Ulmer-Scholle, 2003). A very common process in 715
carbonate environments which allows these events to occur is the formation of 716
hardgrounds or, more suitably, firmgrounds. Formation of firmgrounds requires a halt 717
in sediment deposition and erosion (Demicco and Hardie, 1994; Jones, 2010). This 718
could be caused by the low accommodation space in lowstand, leading to inhibition 719
of growth of the carbonate factory (Bosence and Wilson, 2003; Jones, 2010). In 720
addition, storm eroded firmground material would be readily transported basinward 721
and deposited in high-energy proximal tempestites causing strong progradation 722
(MacNeil and Jones, 2006; Van Steenwinkel, 1990), which is exactly the case in the 723
Irati Sequence 3. Finally, one of the predicted facies model for LST of Burchette and 724
Wright (1992) are the high-energy deposits, such as oolitic grainstones, 725
accommodated in mid- to outer ramp. Since oolite sediments are not abundant in the 726
Irati Formation, this high-energy intraclastic grainstone could be considered an 727
equivalent. 728
The beginning of intercalation of grainstones and heterolithic siltstones (Chw 729
facies; retrogradational pattern), together with abrupt shift in gamma-ray profiles 730
mark the MRS, and so the beginning of the TST. Facies succession is similar to the 731
36
S2I, transiting from mid-ramp facies to outer ramp facies. This systems tract is 732
differentiated, however, by its fossil content. 733
Mesosaurid fossils are present at this interval in all described cores. They are 734
disarticulated, mostly ribs and vertebrae. Breakage, abrasion and corrosion levels 735
vary, but most fossils are well-preserved. There is a clear tendency for concentration 736
around the MTS, but not exactly on it. Mesosaurid fossils become very rare above 2 737
m of the MTS. Fish remains and ichnofossils are also common, and the latter more 738
abundant than at the rest of the studied section. Still, fish fossils are less abundant 739
than mesosaurids. Sulphide nodules are also more common closer to the MTS. All 740
these features are characteristic of the low sedimentation rates of a condensed 741
section, which probably enhanced fossil enrichment. Low sedimentation is also 742
reflected by the limited thickness of the TST when compared to the underlying 743
sequence 744
The restricted interval of occurrence of mesosaurid and pygocephalomorph 745
fossils allowed for the studied outcrops to be correlated and positioned at the SI3, on 746
the upper part of the Assistência Member. The mesosaurid fossils in outcrop occur 747
mostly on the grainstone tempestites beds, in opposition to the occurrences in cores, 748
which are mostly in the heterolithic siltstone. This is probably due to greater 749
resistance of the limestones to weathering in comparison to the highly friable shales 750
and heterolithic facies. The reptile remains can be seen on the outcrops as dense 751
concentrations, often forming a bone-supported fabric (i.e., bonebeds; Eberth et al., 752
2007), generated by storm action (Lavina et al., 1991; Soares, 2003). The vertical 753
distribution of these fossils resembles the biostratigraphic intervals of Hachiro (1996), 754
especially for the restricted occurrence of mesosaurids (Figure 3), which might allow 755
more accurate correlations in future studies. 756
The retrogradational pattern of the TST gives way to a progradational pattern 757
above the MTS, initiating the HST. This systems tract was also deposited with 758
relatively high accommodation space, and less reducing (dysoxic) conditions, 759
indicated by the dark grey mudstones (Araújo, 2001; Boggs, 2006). Fish fossils are 760
also more common in the lower half of the unit. 761
At the top of the studied section, a thin concentration of fish fossils can be found 762
in some cores, near a gamma-ray pattern shift from progradational to 763
37
retrogradational. This surface is interpreted as a transgressive lag (Holz et al., 2010; 764
Lages, 2004; Rohn, 2007), and is therefore considered a sequence boundary to the 765
next sequence, and the end of the Irati Sequences. The contact of the Irati Formation 766
with the Serra Alta Formation is here considered to be at the last appearance of 767
bituminous shale, in accordance to most authors (e.g., Amaral, 1967; Araújo, 2001; 768
Schneider, 1974). Since sequence stratigraphy has different concepts to 769
lithostratigraphy, it was considered more proper to keep the definition of the limits of 770
the units to their own constraints. Thereby, in the studied area the Irati Sequence 3 771
enters the base of the Serra Alta Formation. 772
Deposition of this last sequence initiated with a strong progradation, but not as 773
strong as the underlying sequence. It was followed by a severely sediment-starved 774
TST where an exuberant fauna developed, and was entombed in the increasingly 775
anoxic, sapropelic bottom sediment conditions, unique to the Irati Formation 776
(Pazinato et al., 2016; Piñeiro et al., 2012). Progradation followed in HST with 777
dysoxic conditions and high accommodation space, strengthening the starved 778
sediment interpretation to the TST. 779
5. DISCUSSION 780
5.1. Identification of a Lowstand Systems Tract 781
The results found in the present study are consistent with the works of other 782
researchers in the Irati Formation in the region (e.g., Araújo, 2001; Lavina, 1991; 783
Menezes, 1994; Padula, 1968). Lithostratigraphic limits and fossil content are also 784
very similar (Lavina et al., 1991; Matos et al., 2013; Soares, 2003). The sequence 785
stratigraphy, on the other hand, has important points to be highlighted. 786
The three sequences here recognized are similar to the fourth-order sequences 787
of Araújo (2001), but there are some relevant differences. The sequence boundaries 788
of IS2 and IS3 are traced at the base of the carbonate levels, which are considered 789
as LSTs. As explained in section 4.3.2, the abrupt change in lithology registering a 790
strong progradation of the shoreline, allied with the progradational-aggradational 791
stacking pattern is here considered not likely to have been caused by a normal 792
regression. A LST had already been suggested by Cassel, M.C. (personal 793
38
communication, 2016), while working on boreholes on the same region. In this sense, 794
the sequences become more similar to the fourth-order sequences of Hachiro (1996). 795
Recognition of lowstand systems tracts in carbonate ramps, especially 796
homoclinal ramps, are relatively uncommon (Burchette and Wright, 1992). This is 797
mainly due to their very low relief (less than 1°), which disfavors the formation of 798
incised valleys and lowstand fans and aprons (Wright and Burchette, 1996). Even so, 799
expected characteristics of LSTs in carbonate ramps are strongly progradational 800
units and high-energy deposits of reworked material (Burchette and Wright, 1992; 801
Wright and Burchette, 1996). 802
MacNeil and Jones (2006) describe the reef complexes and associated deposits 803
in a gently sloping, epicontinental ramp of Alexandra Formation, Late Devonian 804
(Frasnian) of Western Canada. The fourth-order sequence of Reef Complex #2 saw 805
an estimated sea-level drop of approximately 17 m, which moved the carbonate 806
factory to the outer ramp. This created a high-producing and high-energy 807
environment, as evidenced by intraclastic grainstones and rudstones, deposited over 808
reefs of the previous HST. The two HST saw little carbonate deposition, and the HST 809
of Sequence #2 is hardly differentiated from the TST on the outer ramp. 810
Differentiation of forced regression from normal regression is due to many factors, 811
including lack of deep to shallow water transitional deposits, and the distance 812
covered by the regressive deposits (around 18 km), which is considered too great for 813
a normal regression. This work shows that a fourth-order sea-level fall can generate 814
a forced regression, even in a low-gradient epicontinental ramp. Also, that carbonate 815
production can be enhanced during lowstand, generating high-energy reworked 816
deposits, similar to the mid-ramp intraclastic grainstone facies of the IS2 and IS3. 817

5.3. Fossil occurrence control 905
Recognition of a stratigraphic framework for the Irati Formation revealed strong 906
facies and sequence control over fossil occurrence in the studied section. Physical 907
factors had a major influence, especially oxygenation levels, storm wave bottom 908
energy, and sediment supply. Unsurprisingly, different fossils had different responses 909
to each set of physical conditions. It is of notice, however, that each of the most 910
abundant fossils (paleonisciforms, pygocephalomorphs, and mesosaurids) is vastly 911
dominant in specific systems tracts. 912
5.3.1. Paleonisciform fish fossils – Early HST 913
Mostly scales and teeth, paleonisciform fish fossils are found isolated or in thin 914
concentrations (Figure 6), and are most common at the early HST of SI1 and SI2. 915
The concentration of these fossils in these specific intervals might be explained by a 916
sedimentation rate “balance”. Deposition on outer ramp environment during the TST 917
is more punctuated, derived from major storm action in between hiatal periods. The 918
fragile fish bones possibly did not resist to prolonged destructive processes on the 919
water-sediment interface, such as dissolution, and possibly biogenic action. On the 920
other hand, increasing sedimentation rate during progradation of the late HST 921
drowned the fossils. 922
Vertebrate accumulations in marine environments are much less studied than 923
their invertebrate counterparts (Rogers & Kidwell, 2000). In addition, when compared 924
to sequence stratigraphy, integrated models are absent even for shelly 925
accumulations (Brett, 1995; Holz & Simões, 2005). So, predictions of vertebrate 926
accumulations in submarine settings in relation to facies, bathymetry, and sequence 927
stratigraphy are even more tentative (Rogers & Kidwell, 2000), although some 928
progress has been made (e.g., Boessenecker et al., 2014; Matos, 2013; Peters et al., 929
2009; Soares, 2003). 930

5.3.2. Pygocephalomorph grainstones – LST 942
The vast majority of pygocephalomorph carapaces occur in grainstones with 943
hummocky, and upper-flow plane-parallel stratification (Cgp facies). This facies 944
contains the “Type C Accumulation” of Matos et al. (2013). These authors highlight 945
how unusual it is for small and thin crustacean carapaces to occur alongside larger 946
mesosaurid bones (up to 4 cm long ribs), even considering early diagenesis 947
mineralization. Another appointed unusual aspect of this accumulation is that the 948
mostly organic pygocephalomorph carapaces would deteriorate in a short period of 949
time, an aspect which caused the authors to evoke mass mortality and simultaneous 950
rapid burial as the process to allow fossilization. 951
In fact, the pygocephalomorph fossils are usually in upper-flow plane-parallel 952
bedding, an even higher-energy structure than the transitional hummocky cross-953
stratification (Dumas and Arnott, 2006) in which the mesosaurids are more commonly 954
found. This can be explained by the carapaces composing sand-sized intraclasts 955
(sometimes up to granule size; Figure 9). The early mineralization and fossilization is 956
explained by hardground or firmground formation due to low accommodation space 957
on a carbonate inner to mid-ramp (Bosence and Wilson, 2003; Demicco and Hardie, 958
1994; Jones, 2010; Pratt, 2010). This indicates these are reworked deposits from 959
previously deposited, semiconsolidated sediments already containing 960
pygocephalomorph fossils. Thus, this fossil concentration is a combination of a hiatal 961
concentration (by firmground formation) and subsequent concentration through 962
reworking caused by storm action (Brett, 1995; Holz and Simões, 2005; Kidwell and 963
44
Bosence, 1991), corroborating the multi-episodic and proximal tempestite 964
interpretations of Matos et al. (2013). 965
On a biostratinomic perspective, the firmground origin interpretation of the 966
present work implies that the storm events were not necessarily a direct cause of 967
death for all the pygocephalomorph individuals. A part of the assemblage might have 968
died of natural causes. Matos et al. (2013) also observes that complete individuals 969
never form dense accumulations. These authors interpret this feature as moments of 970
low abundance of pygocephalomorphs due to stressing conditions (such as 971
hypersalinity, as proposed by Piñeiro et al., 2012), or few occurrences of mass 972
mortality events. Alternatively, this mode of occurrence might represent the normal, 973
“day-to-day” rate of mortality, while the accumulations are the result of diagenetic and 974
reworking events. 975
On the other hand, storms are a known and common cause of animal death and 976
fossil concentration (Brett and Seilacher, 1991; Rogers and Kidwell, 2007), and the 977
preservation characteristics of pygocephalomorph occurrences not contained in 978
intraclasts (type 1 preservation of Matos et al., 2013), usually found in shales are 979
commonly attributed to burial due to distal sediment flows caused by storms (Brett et 980
al., 2012; Brett and Seilacher, 1991). 981
Therefore, the cause of death and accumulation of the pygocephalomorph 982
carapaces are here considered to have a multiple origin. Mass mortality probably did 983
occur episodically, but background bioclastic input might also be registered, and both 984
were enhanced by firmground formation and storm reworking in the LST of the IS3. 985

Mesosaurid bones are composed mainly by disarticulated ribs and vertebrae, 987
although other postcranial elements were also found. They show varied degrees of 988
preservation and fragmentation, and it is possible to observe original relief on the 989
surfaces of some ribs. Breakage is common, mostly straight and transverse (Figure 990
6A). 991
These fossils occur as dense concentrations in the carbonate grainstones in five 992
of the described outcrops (Figure 15A, B), but this condition was not found in cores. 993
Bones commonly support the framework of the rock, and are considered bonebeds 994
45
(Eberth et al., 2007; Fig. 15C, D). They present chaotic orientation, occurring 995
preferentially within the HCS, in the upper portion of tempestites (Figure 15C, D). 996
Semi-articulated individuals are found at the top of HCS beds at the Passo do São 997
Borja outcrop (Figure 9B). Mesosaurids were also found in cores amidst the 998
heterolithic siltstones (Hw facies) at specific intervals in all of the described cores 999
(Figure 6A), and in dense accumulations in the Aceguá 1 outcrop (Figure 15E). 1000
As shown in Figure 13, mesosaurid fossil concentration in outer ramp 1001
environment was enhanced by low sedimentation rates and episodic nature of a 1002
severely sediment-starved TST, with accumulation culminating around the MTS of 1003
IS3, being characterized as a condensed section (section 4.3.3). 1004
Brett (1995) recognizes that TSTs are more prone for fossil accumulation and 1005
better preservation, due to lower background sedimentation rates, and progressive 1006
lower energy. Lower background sedimentation rates prevent “drowning” of the 1007
bioclasts by sediments, and also enhance the action of episodic sedimentation, such 1008
as caused by storms. Thus, preservation modes such as obrution deposits are more 1009
likely to occur, leading sometimes to excellent preservations (lägerstatten; Brett & 1010
Seilacher, 1991). Also, near the MTS, longer permanence of the fossils in the water-1011
sediment interface due to sediment starvation promotes the preservation of 1012
phosphatized fossils, such as vertebrate remains and chitinophosphatic-shelled 1013
brachiopods. This predictive model has been applied successfully to invertebrate 1014
fauna in the Paraná Basin by Simões & Ghilardi (2000) and Zabini et al. (2011). 1015
The propensity of the TST for better fossil preservation seems to be true also for 1016
vertebrate fossils. The works of Rogers & Kidwell (2000), Peters et al. (2009), and 1017
McMullen et al. (2014) all register better preservation and accumulation potential in 1018
the TST, although the modes of fossil occurrence differ in detail. Flooding surfaces 1019
also seem to be very prone to accumulate vertebrate remains by ravinement and 1020
subsequent sediment omission (Boessenecker et al., 2014; Peters et al., 2009; 1021
Rogers & Kidwell, 2000). 1022

6. CONCLUSIONS 1082
Depositional and preservation dynamics in the Whitehill-Irati Sea, and 1083
consequently the rock record of the Irati Formation are the result of a combination of 1084
processes. The main physical factors operating in this environment were: (1) energy 1085
of storm waves affecting bottom sediments (and also lifeforms), controlled by 1086
bathymetry; (2) oxygenation levels at the sediment-water interface, controlled by 1087
quality of water circulation (hindered by water stratification); and (3) rate of sediment 1088
input, terrigenous or carbonate. All of these are in turn controlled by relative sea-level 1089
change. A comprehension of the sequence stratigraphy of this sedimentary 1090
49
succession is thus essential for the comprehension of how these processes 1091
interacted, and resulted in the record of physical conditions, and lifeform activity 1092
found within these rocks. 1093
Concluding remarks of this study are: 1094
1. Three stratigraphic sequences could be recognized for the Irati Formation in 1095
the studied area, termed IS1, IS2, and IS3, and are considered to be of 1096
fourth-order hierarchy. The two overlying sequences, IS2 and IS3, present 1097
lowstand systems tracts. 1098
2. The third-order systems tracts related to the Irati Formation are not 1099
consensus among authors. The findings of this study support the 1100
interpretation of Raffaelli et al. (1996, apud Araújo, 2001) and Milani (1997). 1101
3. The mesosaurid concentrations, along with pygocephalomorph crustaceans 1102
fossil concentrations are restricted to the SI3. This allows correlation of 1103
borehole data with the fossil-bearing outcrops in the Rio Grande do Sul state, 1104
positioning them in the upper Assistência Member. This pattern resembles the 1105
informal biostratigraphy Hachiro (1996). 1106
4. Fossil concentrations are strongly controlled by facies and sequence 1107
stratigraphy (accommodation space and sediment supply). The 1108
paleonisciform fish fossils are the result of a sedimentation rate “balance”: not 1109
too much and not too little. The mesosaurid and pygocephalomorph 1110
accumulations are the result of combined factors: mass mortality and 1111
background bioclastic input enhanced by hiatal and reworked concentrations. 1112
Nature of hiatus is firmground formation for the pygocephalomorphs, and 1113
sediment omission for the mesosaurids. 1114
5. Sequence stratigraphy has proven an excellent tool for the identification and 1115
interpretation of factors controlling sediment deposition, and consequently 1116
fossil occurrence and accumulation. Especially for marine vertebrate 1117
taphonomy, it is greatly underused. This study highlights the great potential of 1118
this tool for aid in explaining the fossil record. 1119
